titleStmt.title: The second Chern class in Spinning System

affiliation.orgName: Institute of Applied Physics and Computational Mathematics

analytic.title: The second Chern class in Spinning System

abstract.p: Topological property in a spinning system should be directly associated with its wavefunction. A complete decomposition formula of SU (2) gauge potential in terms of spinning wavefunction is established rigorously. Based on the φ-mapping theory and this formula, one proves that the second Chern class is inherent in the spinning system. It is showed that this topological invariant is only determined by the Hopf index and Brouwer degree of the spinning wavefunction.

figure.trash: arXiv:hep-th/9909008v1 2 Sep 1999 The second Chern class in Spinning System Yishi Duan 1 , Libin Fu 2, * and Xing Liu 1 1 Physics Department, Lanzhou University, Lanzhou 730000, P.R. China 2 LCP, Institute of Applied Physics and Computational Mathematics, P.O. Box 8009(26), Beijing 100088, P.R. China (December 28, 2013

div.head: Abstract
div.p: Topological property in a spinning system should be directly associated with its wavefunction. A complete decomposition formula of SU (2) gauge potential in terms of spinning wavefunction is established rigorously. Based on the φ-mapping theory and this formula, one proves that the second Chern class is inherent in the spinning system. It is showed that this topological invariant is only determined by the Hopf index and Brouwer degree of the spinning wavefunction.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: Topology now becomes absolutely necessary in physics [1–4]. The φ-mapping theory and the gauge potential decomposition theory [5,6] are found to be significant in exhibiting the topological structure of physics systems [7–10]. Topological properties of a quantum system should be directly associated with its wavefunction. In our previous paper hep-th\ 9908168, based on φ-mapping theory and gauge potential decomposition theory, we reveal the inner relation between the topological property of Schrödinger system and the intrinsic properties of its wavefunction. We point out that a topological invariant, the first Chern class, is inherent in the Schrödinger system, which is only associated with the wave function.
This intrinsic relation is the topological source of the inner structure of London equations in superconductor [10].

In this paper, we extend our work to spinning system. Based on the gauge potential decomposition theory, we investigate the SU(2) gauge potential in terms of the spinning wavefunction. The complete decomposition formula of the SU(2) gauge potential is obtained rigorously. By making use of this result, the second Chern class is studied. One proves that the second Chern class is exclusively labeled by the topological index of the spinning wavefunction without using any particular models or hypotheses. In other words, one shows that the second Chern class is inherent in spinning system. This relation between Chern class and wavefunction is intrinsic property of quantum system, and gives a basic concept in topological quantum mechanics.

figure.trash: II. SU (2) GAUGE POTENTIAL IN TERMS OF SPINNING WAVEFUNCTION Considering a spinning wavefunction ψ =     ψ 1 ψ 2     , we have the convariant derivative denoted as Dψ = dψ − Aψ, (1) where A = i 2 A a σ a (a = 1, 2, 3) is a SU(2) gauge potential, and σ a is the Pauli Matrices. Its complex conjugate is given by Dψ + = dψ + + ψ + A, (2) in which ψ + = ψ 1 * ψ 2 * . By making use of the equation σ a σ b + σ b σ a = 2Iδ ab , one can prove that A a = − i ψ + ψ [(ψ + σ a dψ − dψ + σ a ψ) − (ψ + σ a Dψ − Dψ + σ a ψ)]. (3) From this formula, it can be proved that A a = − i ψ + ψ T r(dψψ + σ a − ψdψ + σ a ) + i ψ + ψ T r(Dψψ + σ a − ψDψ + σ a ). (4) Using the properties of Pauli matrices and considering T r(A) = 0, we can obtain that A = 1 ψ + ψ [(dψψ + − ψdψ + ) − T r(dψψ + − ψdψ + )I] − 1 ψ + ψ [(Dψψ + − ψDψ + ) − T r(Dψψ + − ψDψ + )I]. (5) From (5), it is easy to prove that A satisfies the gauge transformation A ′ = SAS −1 + dSS −1 , under the SU(2) transformation ψ ′ = Sψ, ψ ′ + = ψ + S + . Here, we know that S + = S −1 .

div.p: The main feature of the decomposition theory of the gauge potential is that the gauge potential A can be generally decomposed as [5,6,11] A = a + b, where a and b are required to satisfy the following respective transformation

figure.trash: a ′ = SaS −1 + dSS −1 , (6) b = SbS −1 . (7) Investigating Eq. (5), one finds that the SU(2) gauge potential can be decomposed as a = 1 ψ + ψ [(dψψ + − ψdψ + ) − T r(dψψ + − ψdψ + )I], (8) and b = − 1 ψ + ψ [(Dψψ + − ψDψ + ) − T r(Dψψ + − ψDψ + )I], (9) which satisfy the Eqs. (6) and (7) respectively.

div.p: We know that the topological property is independent with the choice of the gauge potential [4]. So, we can take A as A = 1 ψ + ψ [(dψψ
One can regard it as a special gauge. In fact, this choice is equal to the common condition,
Dψ = 0, which is often used in studying spinning problem.
On the other hand, the spinning wavefunction can be denoted as

figure.figDesc: ) are real function. One can regard the spinning wavefunction as the complex representation of a vector field
figure.trash: φ = (φ 1 , φ 2 , φ 3 , φ 4 ). Let us define a unit vector n as n a = φ a ||φ|| , ||φ|| = (φ a φ a ) 1 2 = (ψ + ψ) 1 2 , (11) and n a n a = 1. (12) If we denote that N =     n 1 + in 2 n 3 + in 4     , N + = n 1 − in 2 n 3 − in 4 , then one has N + N = n a n a = 1 (13) The expression (10) can be rewrote as A = (NdN + − dNN + ) − T r(NdN + − dNN + )I. (14)

div.head: III. THE SECOND CHERN CLASS INHERITS IN SPINNING SYSTEM
div.p: We know that the unit vector n can be expressed in terms of Clifford algebra [12,13] as

figure.trash: n = n A s A , A = 0, 1, 2, 3. (15) with n 0 = n 4 , and where s = (I, i σ), s † = (I, −i σ). (16) Then one can rewrite (12) as nn † = 1. (17) If we choose the spinor as ψ =     φ 1 − iφ 2 −φ 3 − iφ 4   
figure.figDesc:  , it can be proved that the gauge potential A given in (14) has the expression as

div.p: It is interesting that this result is the same as the decomposition formula of the SU(2) gauge potential in terms of a four-dimensional vector field which we have obtained in [11].
One knows that the second Chern class can be wrote in terms of Chern-Simon [4,14]

figure.trash: C 2 (P ) = 1 8π 2 dΩ, (19) and Ω = 1 8π 2 T r A ∧ dA − 2 3 A ∧ A ∧ A (20)

div.p: which is known as Chern-Simon form [15].

figure.trash: Substituting (18) into (19) and considering (17), we obtain C 2 (P ) = 1 24π 2 T r(dn ∧ dn † ∧ dn ∧ dn † ). (21) From (15), one gets C 2 (P ) = 1 24π 2 ∈ µνλρ ∂ µ n A ∂ ν n B ∂ λ n C ∂ρn D T r s A s † B s C s † D dx 4 = 1 12π 2 ∈ µνλρ ∈ ABCD ∂ µ n A ∂ ν n B ∂ λ n C ∂ ρ n D dx 4 . (22) By substituting (11) into (22), and considering dn A = dφ A ||φ|| + φ A d 1 ||φ|| , (23) we have C 2 (P ) = − 1 4π 2 ∂ 2 ∂φ A ∂φ A 1 ||φ|| 2 D (φ/x) d 4 x, (24) where D(φ/x) is the Jacobian defined as ∈ ABCD D (φ/x) =∈ µνλρ ∂ µ φ A ∂νφ B ∂ λ φ C ∂ ρ φ D . (25) By means of the general Green function formula ∂ 2 ∂φ A ∂φ A 1 ||φ|| 2 = −4πδ 4 φ , (26) we get C 2 (P ) = δ 4 φ D (φ/x) d 4 x. (27) Suppose φ A (x) (A = 0, 1, 2, 3

div.p: ) have m isolated zeros at x µ = z i µ (i = 1, 2, · · ·, m) , according to the δ-Function theory [2]

figure.trash: , δ( φ) can be expressed by δ( φ) = m i=1 β i δ( x − z i ) |D(φ/x)| x= z i , (28) and one then obtains C 2 (P ) = m i=1 η i β i δ 4 (x − z i ) d 4 x, (29)

div.p: where β i is a positive integer (the Hopf index of the ith zeros ) and η i is the Brouwer degree [16]

The meaning of the Hopf index β i is that the vector field function φ covers the corresponding region β i times while x covers the region neighborhood of zero z i once. From above discussion, the Chern density ρ(x) is defined as :

figure.trash: ρ(x) = m i=1 η i β i δ 4 (x − z i ) , (31)

div.p: which shows that the topological structure of Chern density ρ is labeled by the Brouwer degrees and the Hopf index. The integration of ρ(x)

figure.trash: C 2 = ρ(x)d 4 x = m i=1 η i β i (32)

div.p: is integer called Chern number which is a topological invariant.

The result (32) suggests that the topological invariant is determined only by the zero points of the vector field φ, i.e. the zeroes of the spinning wavefunction ψ. The topological indexes of zero points are intrinsic properties of the wavefunction, so the topological invariant given in (32) is naturally inherent in the spinning system.

div.head: IV. DISCUSSION
div.p: Based on the gauge potential decomposition method, we established the gauge potential decomposition theory in terms of the spinning wavefunction. One finds that the SU(2) gauge potential can be completely decomposed by the wavefunction of spinning system. By making use of the φ-mapping theory, we reveal that the second Chern class is naturally inherent in spinning system, which is only associated with the intrinsic properties of the spinning wavefunction, and labeled by the topological indexes of the wavefunction. We believe that this intrinsic topological property is a fundamental property of quantum system and is the source of many topological effects in quantum system. This gives a new concept in topological quantum mechanics.

div.head: ACKNOWLEDGMENTS
div.p: This work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China.
